abstract.text: No overview available.
Fit the queried items to fill their parent/reference/guide by
a percentage along vertical/horizontal axes or both.
Does not center items, however, if the item is previously
centered it should maintain center since the change is to bounds.
Update the queried item’s width to match the reference item,
with optional adjusted width to be added to reference width.
Update the queried item’s y value relative to reference.
Link queried items together edge-to-edge horizontally,
with an optional offset. Default is .max edge to .min edge.
See also link() for more options.
Spread queried items evenly (or randomly) along an axis (or axes) within their
parent/reference so that items are
to fit the available space
minus inter-item spacing and/or edge insets.
Use negative spacing to create overlap between items.
If the spacing exceeds the available space, items may disappear or
flow beyond their parent/reference.
Update the queried item’s height to match the reference item.
with optional adjusted height to be added to reference height.
Disperse a
of items along both axes within parent/reference.
Specify the number of items for the first axis (width or height edge)
which are dispersed along that axis, and subsequently disperse items
on the cross axis (width or height edge) such that all items will
be dispersed on both axis, potentially forming a “grid” or similar
dispersed structure.
Provide insets to control where the items start and/or end, or
omit insets to disperse the items evenly within the edges.
For example, omitting the insets provides even spacing before and
after items equal to the spacing between the items.
To pin items to the edges (with equal spacing) use inset of 0.0
or other specific value.
Without insets, if the items do not fit in their container they
will “spill over” but remain centered relative to the container.
In this case, insets may be provided to force the items to remain
within the container, in which case the items will overlap each other.
Optionally provide “grouper” trailing closure to further refine
how items should be grouped on the cross-axis (e.g. in the case of
using “width” (aka “horizontal”) the cross-axis for dispersion is “vertical”).
The closure is passed an item index and the current item and must return
a hashable value to logically group the items for dispersion on the
cross-axis. TIP: The hashable return value may also be an instance of
IndexedAlignment() for advanced post-grouping alignment. Example:
Update the queried item’s frames relative to reference.
Value mutation affects all provided values.
Accepts absolute (e.g. 100.0) or percentile values (e.g. 50% or %0.5)
Pin the queried items so that they stretch to fit their
parent/reference/guide between top and bottom edges,
with optional insets (above/below).
Align the edge of queried items to an anchor item. Anchor may be
specified via closure from the current query or as a compatible
reference item. Otherwise, it will default to aligning everything
to the first item.
To align to parent item (in case of diverse alignments) return
parent from anchor closure, e.g. align(..) { $0.parent }.
The relation must be the same type as the item type. If this is a problem
then cast the query to the most general type, e.g.
Providing one edge will align both items and anchor on that edge.
Providing an additional anchor edge will align the item edge to
the anchor edge. For example, align(.top) will align the top edge
of each item to the top edge of the anchor item (similar to “pin”).
Wheras, align(.top, with:.bottom) will align the top edge of each
item with the bottom edge of the anchor item.
Positive offsets add spacing
from origin (toward bottom-trailing).
Offset respects layout direction (i.e. it goes
origin).
“Offset” is not to be confused with “insets”.
Use .flex option to align a “flexible” edge to any other attribute
while maintaining the position of the opposite edge, effectively
stretching the item from the opposite edge to the alignment edge.
See also other align() method for more specialized alignments.
Link queried items together edge-to-edge vertically,
with an optional offset. Default is .max edge to .min edge.
See also link() for more options.
Stretch the queried items to fit their parent/reference/guide
between leading and trailing edges, with optional insets (before/after).
Update the queried item’s x value relative to reference.
Update the queried item’s origin relative to reference.
Stretch the queried items to fit to their parent or reference
item, providing optional inset value. For more control over edge
and inset see other pin() method. Optionally, provide
that should be stretched to fit.
Pin to left edge if condition is true, otherwise
pin to right edge (with optional insets).
Pin the queried items to any side or sides of the parent
or reference item, providing an optional inset value.
To support flexible sizes, pin to opposing sides (with insets).
NOTE: in order for flexible pinning to work, the opposing
sides should be specified in one call, e.g. pin([.top,.bottom])
and
.pin(.top).pin(.bottom). To support the latter,
use flex sizing: .pin(.top).mutate(.flex).pin(.bottom).
See also convenience API pinHorizontally/Vertically.
Basic pinning.
Pin the queried items to all edges of their parent or reference
item, providing optional inset value. For more control over edge
and inset see other pin() method.
Link queried items together edge-to-edge along any axis,
with an optional x/y offset. Default is .max edge to .min edge.
The first edge can be changed to .mid (to make items overlap
from their mid point, or .mid edge to .min edge) or .min
(to make items overlap on the same edge, or .min edge to
.min edge. Add offset to provide overlap otherwise the items
will be on top of each other). To reverse the direction of
linking (towards origin) use inverse param.
The first linked item must have it’s position already set on the
axis of the linking operation, else it will default to 0.0
origin for that axis (not respecting parent guides if any).
build {
Item1().in($0).leading() // positioning is required
Item2().in($0)
.centerVertically()
.linkHorizontally() // link starting at item 1 leading
Spread queried items evenly (or randomly) along vertical axis within their
parent/reference so that items are
to fit the available space
minus inter-item spacing and/or edge insets.
Use negative spacing to create overlap between items.
If the spacing exceeds the available space, items may disappear or
flow beyond their parent/reference.
Update the queried item’s width relative to reference.
Optionally specify for the height to match the width
(particularly useful where width is percentage-based).
Wrapper for mutation of an item’s size, position, etc.
Align the “edge”, “center”, or “typo”graphic attribute of queried
items to an anchor item. Alternatively, align using absolute or
percentile values relative to the item/anchor, via the “at” operator.
Alignment axis is inferred. (NOTE: When using “center” or “at” operators
it is not normally necessary to specify axis as that will be inferred.)
Anchor may be specified via closure from the current query or as a
compatible reference item. Otherwise, the anchor will default to
aligning everything to the first item of a multiple item query
or, for convenience for a single item query, to the item’s parent.
To align to parent/ancestor (or any other relation) on a multiple item
query return the relation from the closure, e.g. align(..) { $0.parent }.
The relation must be the same type as the item type. If this is a problem
then cast the query to the most general type, e.g.
Providing one alignment will align both items and anchor on that
alignment. Providing an additional anchor alignment will align
the item alignment to the anchor alignment.
For example, align(.edge(.top)) will align the top edge of each
item to the top edge of the anchor item (similar to “pin”).
Wheras, align(.edge(.top), with:.edge(.bottom)) will align the
top edge of each item with the bottom edge of the anchor item.
Positive offsets add spacing
from origin (toward bottom-trailing).
Offset respects layout direction (i.e. it goes
origin
in the case of right-to-left layout).
“Offset” is not to be confused with “insets”.
Using .center(.both) in combination with other alignments “works”
but is considered “magical”. See also centering API.
Use .flex option to align a “flexible” edge to any other attribute
while maintaining the position of the opposite edge, effectively
stretching the item from the opposite edge to the alignment edge.
Update the queried item’s size relative to reference.
Spread a
of items items evenly (or randomly) along both axes within
their parent/reference so that items are
to fit the available space
minus inter-item spacing and/or edge insets. Specify the number of items
for the first axis (width or height edge) to be spread along that axis,
and subsequently spread items on the cross axis (width or height
edge) such that all items will be spread on both axis, potentially forming
a “grid” or similar structure.
Use negative spacing to create overlap between items.
If the spacing exceeds the available space, items may disappear or
flow beyond their parent/reference.
Optionally provide “grouper” trailing closure to further refine
how items should be grouped on the cross-axis (e.g. in the case of
using “width” (aka “horizontal”) the cross-axis for dispersion is “vertical”).
The closure is passed an item index and the current item and must return
a hashable value to logically group the items for dispersion on the
cross-axis. TIP: The hashable return value may also be an instance of
IndexedAlignment() for advanced post-grouping alignment. Example:
Center items horizontally relative to their parent or reference
item without affecting their current vertical position(s).
Value mutation affects offset only.
Pin the queried items so that they stretch to fit their
parent/reference/guide between leading and trailing edges,
with optional insets (before/after).
Disperse items evenly (or randomly) along horizontal axis within parent/reference.
Provide insets to control where the items start and/or end, or omit
both insets to disperse the items evenly within the edges.
For example to provide even spacing before and after items
equal to the spacing between the items, omit the insets.
To pin items to the edges (with equal spacing) use inset of 0.0.
Without insets, if the items do not fit in their container they
will “spill over” but remain centered relative to the container.
In this case, insets may be provided to force the items to remain
within the container, in which case the items will overlap each other.
Disperse items evenly (or randomly) along vertical axis within parent/reference.
Provide insets to control where the items start and/or end, or omit
both insets to disperse the items evenly within the edges.
For example to provide even spacing before and after items
equal to the spacing between the items, omit the insets.
To pin items to the edges (with equal spacing) use inset of 0.0.
Without insets, if the items do not fit in their container they
will “spill over” but remain centered relative to the container.
In this case, insets may be provided to force the items to remain
within the container, in which case the items will overlap each other.
Update the queried item’s size to match the reference item,
with optional adjusted size to be added on one or both axes.
Spread queried items evenly (or randomly) along horizontal axis within their
parent/reference so that items are
to fit the available space
minus inter-item spacing and/or edge insets.
Use negative spacing to create overlap between items.
If the spacing exceeds the available space, items may disappear or
flow beyond their parent/reference.
Disperse items evenly (or randomly) along an axis within parent/reference.
Provide insets to control where the items start and/or end, or
omit insets to disperse the items evenly within the edges.
For example, omitting the insets provides even spacing before and
after items equal to the spacing between the items.
To pin items to the edges (with equal spacing) use inset of 0.0
or other specific value.
Without insets, if the items do not fit in their container they
will “spill over” but remain centered relative to the container.
In this case, insets may be provided to force the items to remain
within the container, in which case the items will overlap each other.
Update the queried item’s height relative to reference.
Optionally specify for the width to match the height
(particularly useful where height is percentage-based).
Center items vertically relative to their parent or reference
item without affecting their current horizontal position(s).
Value mutation affects offset only.
Pin to leading edge if condition is true, otherwise
pin to trailing edge (with optional insets).
Fit the queried items to fill their parent/reference/guide
according to specific area (top, middle, etc) with fractional
value and optional inset for the perpendicular sides.
Fractional value can be expressed as:
Center items relative to their parent or reference item.
Optionally specify axis and/or offsets.
Supports randomization or deviation of center position
(via .random option and/or deviation value).
Offsets support accumulation if used (via .cumulative option).
Pin the queried items to any edge or edges of the parent
or reference item, providing insets for each each (dictionary).
Advanced pinning.
Update the queried item’s to have equal height and width,
or if using percentage based value, the same relative
percentage, which if the reference/container is non-square
will result in diverse height and width.
Stretch the queried items to fit their parent/reference/guide
between top and bottom edges, with optional insets (above/below).
Pin to top edge if condition is true, otherwise
pin to bottom edge (with optional insets).
